posts._title: Valerie Buhagiar – Tell Us the Truth Josephine (2006)
posts.title: Tell Us the Truth Josephine
posts.excerpt: DVD box wrote: Tell Us The Truth Josephine is an experimental drama about a Maltese immigrant woman walking across Canada on stilts in search for home. Her journey, however, is haunted by stories of her past. It is only once she accepts these stories, and the truth, that she can land and truly find home.

posts._title: Yasujiro Ozu – Ohayô aka Good Morning (1959)
posts.title: Ohayô
posts.excerpt: Quote: “Sooner or later, everyone who loves movies comes to Ozu. He is the quietest and gentlest of directors, the most humanistic, the most serene.” — Roger Ebert It took long enough, but I sampled my first Yasujiro Ozu film, Good Morning (Ohayo), and will soon indulge myself with as many of his works as …

posts.title: All Good Children
posts.excerpt: After the death of their mother, Irish youngsters Dara and Eoin are moved to France to stay with their aunt. There, the boys befriend a local English family and the impressionable Dara falls under the spell of their young daughter Bella. But when she begins to pull away, Dara’s feelings for her start to get …

posts.title: The Gold Rush
posts.excerpt: Dave Kehr, Chicago Reader wrote: Charles Chaplin’s best-loved film, with the tramp down-and-out (as usual) in Alaska, where he looks for gold, falls in love with a dance-hall girl (Georgia Hale), eats his shoes for Thanksgiving dinner, and ends up a millionaire. The blend of slapstick and pathos is seamless, although the cynicism of the …

posts._title: Marco Ferreri – La Dernière femme AKA The Last Woman (1976)
posts.title: La Dernière femme
posts.excerpt: Gérard (26 year-old G.Depardieu in a star-making, César-nominated performance) is the he-man single father of a little baby boy who meets carefree, sensuous Valérie (ravishingly beautiful 21 year-old Ornella Muti). They feel instantly attracted to each other, she moves in with him on the spot, they fall in love, she fancies playing stepmother to the …

posts.title: Kiss of Death
posts.excerpt: Quote: Based in part on a true story, Kiss of Death is given a veneer of reality by being filmed on location in New York, with a bare minimum of studio work. In one of his best performances, Victor Mature plays a cheap crook who is sent up the river for 20 years for robbery. …

posts._title: Alfred Hitchcock – Dial M for Murder (1954)
posts.title: Dial M for Murder
posts.excerpt: M stands for murder and also for mindfuck in this, one of Hitchcock’s best films. Based on a stage play by Frederick Knott (whose credits also include another great thriller, Wait Until Dark), Dial M For Murder includes one of the most intricate plots of any murder mystery as well as maximum amounts of Hitchcock’s …

posts._title: Carlos Marques-Marcet – 10.000 Km AKA Long Distance (2014)
posts.title: 10000 Km
posts.excerpt: Quote: ONE YEAR, TWO COMPUTERS AND AN OCEAN BETWEEN THEM One couple, one year apart and two distant cities: Los Angeles and Barcelona. Love is Alexandra and Sergio’s only weapon and their computers their only tools to fight the 10,000 kilometers that stand in the way of their future together.

posts.title: Q
posts.excerpt: Review from thefilmdb.co.uk Q’ opens with a heavy dose of nudity – a shower scene shot from the neck down as multiple naked women engage in conversation. We don’t see their faces, just their bodies. Writer/director Laurent Bouhnik holds the shot long enough for the scene to evolve from titilation into something more, establishing leaders …

posts._title: Youssef Chahine – Bab el hadid AKA Cairo Station (1958)
posts.title: Bab el hadid
posts.excerpt: Quote: Universally panned by Egypt’s cinema audiences when it was first released in 1958, Youssef Chahine’s “Cairo Station” disappeared from view for two decades until it was rediscovered and hailed as a masterpiece. Watching the film now, almost half a century after its first screening, it’s easy to see why it upset so many people …
